37.text: The 45  Mile exploration project lies some  15 km SSE off the Bottle Creek Gold Mine

38.text: ofNorth Broken Hill/Peko Ltd,  130 km  SW of Leonora and 70  km NW  of Menzies.

39.text: The  current  tenements  extend  from  51  Mile  Well  in the  north,  southward to  the  45

40.text: Mile Well.  Access across the project area is well provided for  by a number of station

41.text: tracks. The project lies on Riverina Pastoral Station within  the Menzies Shire.

44.text: The triangular E29/130  and  P29/1253,  approximately  12  km x 4 km,  occupied some

45.text: 32  sq km and is  bisected by the  Copperfield- Menzies  Road.  P29/1253  expired on

46.text: 28  May  1995  and was  surrendered.  E29130  was  granted on 30/4/91.  The tenement

47.text: lies  on the  Snake Hill and  Walling Rock  1:50000  sheets.  A  50% tenement reduction

48.text: was made in 1994, the area then being reduced to  15.3  km2

50.text: from 4th  year tenement reduction was lodged with DOME on 10/4/95.  The project is

51.text: a Joint Venture between Townson Holdings Pty Ltd and Mr J Anania (Fig. I).

52.text: In November 1995, the EL was repegged as two  surveyed MLs, viz MLA 29/181  and

53.text: MLA 29/182,  and  the  previous  PL  as  PLA  29/1534  (see  Table  1).  Approval  given

54.text: and tenements were granted in August 2003  .  PL 29/1534 was not renewed.

text:
The 45  Mile exploration project lies some  15 km SSE off the Bottle Creek Gold Mine 
 ofNorth Broken Hill/Peko Ltd,  130 km  SW of Leonora and 70  km NW  of Menzies. 
 The  current  tenements  extend  from  51  Mile  Well  in the  north,  southward to  the  45 
 Mile Well.  Access across the project area is well provided for  by a number of station 
 tracks. The project lies on Riverina Pastoral Station within  the Menzies Shire. 
 The triangular E29/130  and  P29/1253,  approximately  12  km x 4 km,  occupied some 
 32  sq km and is  bisected by the  Copperfield- Menzies  Road.  P29/1253  expired on 
 28  May  1995  and was  surrendered.  E29130  was  granted on 30/4/91.  The tenement 
 lies  on the  Snake Hill and  Walling Rock  1:50000  sheets.  A  50% tenement reduction 
 was made in 1994, the area then being reduced to  15.3  km2
 •  A request for  exemption 
 from 4th  year tenement reduction was lodged with DOME on 10/4/95.  The project is 
 a Joint Venture between Townson Holdings Pty Ltd and Mr J Anania (Fig. I). 
 In November 1995, the EL was repegged as two  surveyed MLs, viz MLA 29/181  and 
 MLA 29/182,  and  the  previous  PL  as  PLA  29/1534  (see  Table  1).  Approval  given 
 and tenements were granted in August 2003  .  PL 29/1534 was not renewed.

37.text: The  environmental impact of exploration activities  is  kept to  a minimum.  Access  to

38.text: the  tenements  is  made  using  existing  fence  lines  and  station  tracks.  Gridding  is

39.text: mostly been accomplished using hand methods with machinery only being used when

40.text: absolutely  necessary.  Where  clearing  is  necessary,  approval  is  sought  from  the

41.text: Pastoralist  and  District  Mining  Engineer  DIOR.  All  drill  sites  and  camp  sites  are

42.text: cleaned of rubbish and drillholes plugged or capped.  Clearing is undertaken using a

43.text: bulldozer fitted with a rake, which encourages quicker regrowth.

text:
The  environmental impact of exploration activities  is  kept to  a minimum.  Access  to 
 the  tenements  is  made  using  existing  fence  lines  and  station  tracks.  Gridding  is 
 mostly been accomplished using hand methods with machinery only being used when 
 absolutely  necessary.  Where  clearing  is  necessary,  approval  is  sought  from  the 
 Pastoralist  and  District  Mining  Engineer  DIOR.  All  drill  sites  and  camp  sites  are 
 cleaned of rubbish and drillholes plugged or capped.  Clearing is undertaken using a 
 bulldozer fitted with a rake, which encourages quicker regrowth.

50.text: Following a major gear failure  in the SAG Mill and the closure of the VB pit

51.text: due  to  the  failure  of the  western  wall,  operations  were  placed  on  care  and

52.text: maintenance.  A  re-appraisal  of EMU,  Southwark and Boags was  undertaken.

53.text: Some  60,000  t  of ore  remained  on  the  ROM  pad  and  accessible  reserves

55.text: The  EMU  reserve  was  cut  by  some  70%.  A  minor  laterite  resource  was

56.text: established  at  Southwark.  Milling  re-commenced  in  April  90  treating  ROM

57.text: material  and  ore  from  Boags  which  was  exhausted  by  Dec  90.  Low  grade

58.text: stockpiles  were also treated.  Rehabilitation was undertaken in early  1991  and

59.text: the  mine  closed.  The  mine  remained  in mothballs  until  April  1993  when the

 material  and  ore  from  Boags  which  was  exhausted  by  Dec  90.  Low  grade

 the  mine  closed.  The  mine  remained  in mothballs  until  April  1993  when the

55.text: evident. Later events caused large scale folds  on NE and ESE axial plunge directions.

56.text: The deformation history of the western ironstone appears to be more complex than the

57.text: eastern terrain. Bottle Creek appears to lie at the break between the two terrains.

58.text: The  Ularring  greenstone  belt  comprises  a  north-northwest-striking,  east-dipping

59.text: greenstone  succession  surrounded  by  variably  deformed  adamellitic  rocks.  The

60.text: western  extent  of  the  greenstone  succession  is  marked  by  a  laterally  extensive

61.text: sequence of banded iron formations (BIFs), interspersed with dolerites. The remainder

62.text: of the  belt  is  dominated  by  high-magnesium  basalts  which  are  intercalated  with

63.text: interflow  sedimentary  rocks  (black  shales  and  cherts).  A  prominent  tholeiitic  unit

64.text: occurs  in  the  centre  of the  belt  to  the  north  and  is  replaced  by  a  black  shale/felsic

65.text: porphyry  complex  further  to  the  south.  Komatiitic  sequences  (Walter  Williams

66.text: Formation) are intercalated with high-magnesium basalts in the eastern portion of the

67.text: belt.  Numerous  dolerite  sills  intrude  the  mafic/ultramafic  succession  and  are

text:
evident. Later events caused large scale folds  on NE and ESE axial plunge directions. 
 The deformation history of the western ironstone appears to be more complex than the 
 eastern terrain. Bottle Creek appears to lie at the break between the two terrains. 
 The  Ularring  greenstone  belt  comprises  a  north-northwest-striking,  east-dipping 
 greenstone  succession  surrounded  by  variably  deformed  adamellitic  rocks.  The 
 western  extent  of  the  greenstone  succession  is  marked  by  a  laterally  extensive 
 sequence of banded iron formations (BIFs), interspersed with dolerites. The remainder 
 of the  belt  is  dominated  by  high-magnesium  basalts  which  are  intercalated  with 
 interflow  sedimentary  rocks  (black  shales  and  cherts).  A  prominent  tholeiitic  unit 
 occurs  in  the  centre  of the  belt  to  the  north  and  is  replaced  by  a  black  shale/felsic 
 porphyry  complex  further  to  the  south.  Komatiitic  sequences  (Walter  Williams 
 Formation) are intercalated with high-magnesium basalts in the eastern portion of the 
 belt.  Numerous  dolerite  sills  intrude  the  mafic/ultramafic  succession  and  are

33.text: The major tectonic feature in the region is the Mt.  Ida Lineament, to the east of Bottle

34.text: Creek.  Its  presence may  explain the  non-existence of BIF on the  eastern side  of the

35.text: Kurragong  anticline.  There  is  also  a possibility that  a  tectonic  break  exists  to  the

36.text: west of Bottle Creek, because rocks in the greenstone belt dip sub-vertically, whereas

37.text: the BIF units to the west dip at much shallower angles.

38.text: The Bottle Creek structure may be a splay off of the Mt.  Ida Lineament, or the Bottle

39.text: Creek  shear  was  a  result  of the  intrusion  of the  Copperfield  and  Fountain  Spring

40.text: Granites, which formed a dextral wrench shear system.

41.text: Exposure  of the  Bottle  Creek  gold  deposit  through  excavation  of the  open  pits  has

42.text: confirmed that the  deposit  is  hosted within  an  approximately  50  m  wide  shear zone

43.text: near the  western boundary of a quartz  porphyry  intrusion.  The mineralisation within

44.text: this zone is concentrated within a sulphidic and graphitic silicified-shale horizon (the

45.text: cherty nature is probably due to  silica introduced by ore fluids)  which is usually less

46.text: than 10m wide.  Wall rocks can carry economic mineralisation, although they usually

47.text: contain less than  0.2  ppm Au.  Although it is possible that this sediment horizon did

48.text: contain some syngenetic gold, evidence suggests that most of the gold was introduced

49.text: via  fluids  associated  with  shearing and  porphyry  emplacement,  with  the  graphite  in

50.text: the  sediment  probably  responsible  for  the  deposition  of metals  (including  Au)  from

51.text: the  ore  solutions.  The  importance  of  this  shearing  (and  consequent  porphyry

52.text: emplacement)  is  emphasised  because  other  primary  gossans  not  associated  with

53.text: shearing  exist  within the  Bottle  Creek area,  and  these  have  been rock  chip  sampled

54.text: and in some cases drilled and shown to  contain only background levels of Au ( <0.1 0

55.text: ppm). Also, other Archaean shale-hosted deposits show good evidence that economic

56.text: concentrations of gold are obtained only where epigenetic fluids have been introduced

59.text: The area is covered for the most part by Tertiary laterite and recent eluvial, alluvial or

60.text: aeolian  deposits.  The  Archaean  sub-surface  geology  from  west  to  east  consists  of

61.text: Pianto's  granite  and  granitoid basement  overlain  by  a  sequence  of sediments,  mafic

62.text: and  ultramafic  rock types.  This  sequence  forms  portions  of the  western limbs of the

63.text: Kurrajong and Snake Hill anticlines which have been intruded by felsic porphyries. A

text:
The major tectonic feature in the region is the Mt.  Ida Lineament, to the east of Bottle 
 Creek.  Its  presence may  explain the  non-existence of BIF on the  eastern side  of the 
 Kurragong  anticline.  There  is  also  a possibility that  a  tectonic  break  exists  to  the 
 west of Bottle Creek, because rocks in the greenstone belt dip sub-vertically, whereas 
 the BIF units to the west dip at much shallower angles. 
 The Bottle Creek structure may be a splay off of the Mt.  Ida Lineament, or the Bottle 
 Creek  shear  was  a  result  of the  intrusion  of the  Copperfield  and  Fountain  Spring 
 Granites, which formed a dextral wrench shear system. 
 Exposure  of the  Bottle  Creek  gold  deposit  through  excavation  of the  open  pits  has 
 confirmed that the  deposit  is  hosted within  an  approximately  50  m  wide  shear zone 
 near the  western boundary of a quartz  porphyry  intrusion.  The mineralisation within 
 this zone is concentrated within a sulphidic and graphitic silicified-shale horizon (the 
 cherty nature is probably due to  silica introduced by ore fluids)  which is usually less 
 than 10m wide.  Wall rocks can carry economic mineralisation, although they usually 
 contain less than  0.2  ppm Au.  Although it is possible that this sediment horizon did 
 contain some syngenetic gold, evidence suggests that most of the gold was introduced 
 via  fluids  associated  with  shearing and  porphyry  emplacement,  with  the  graphite  in 
 the  sediment  probably  responsible  for  the  deposition  of metals  (including  Au)  from 
 the  ore  solutions.  The  importance  of  this  shearing  (and  consequent  porphyry 
 emplacement)  is  emphasised  because  other  primary  gossans  not  associated  with 
 shearing  exist  within the  Bottle  Creek area,  and  these  have  been rock  chip  sampled 
 and in some cases drilled and shown to  contain only background levels of Au ( <0.1 0 
 ppm). Also, other Archaean shale-hosted deposits show good evidence that economic 
 concentrations of gold are obtained only where epigenetic fluids have been introduced 
 The area is covered for the most part by Tertiary laterite and recent eluvial, alluvial or 
 aeolian  deposits.  The  Archaean  sub-surface  geology  from  west  to  east  consists  of 
 Pianto's  granite  and  granitoid basement  overlain  by  a  sequence  of sediments,  mafic 
 and  ultramafic  rock types.  This  sequence  forms  portions  of the  western limbs of the 
 Kurrajong and Snake Hill anticlines which have been intruded by felsic porphyries. A

32.text: Previous gold exploration work by Norgold/Geopeko on their Jackson Bore (45  Mile)

33.text: project included stream sediment and limited soil sampling, followed by three E-W  1

34.text: km  spaced  RAB  drill  hole  traverses  at  40  m  hole  intervals.  The  three  traverses  are

35.text: located in the northern most portion of the EL.  No  significant results >0.18  Au ppm

36.text: Au  were  encountered.  However,  anomalous  arsenic  values  up  to  1200  ppm  were

37.text: found. The exploration work failed to delineate a Bottle Creek style horizon.

38.text: Weak  gold  anomalies  were  found  in  stream  sediments  in  the  northern  area  of the

39.text: tenement.  These  are  probably  the  result  of leakage  into  the  drainage  from  the  old

42.text: Initial  work by Townson  during  1991  included:  examination of Geopeko  data;  the

45.text: mapping;  coupled  with  field  inspections.  This  work  has  indicated  that  the  EL  was

46.text: prospective for a number of styles of mineralisation, including that of the Bottle Creek

47.text: deposits.  Followup  work  included  RAB  drilling  and  mapping.  During  1992  an

48.text: interpretation using stress mapping technology was completed.  From 1993-97 further

49.text: RAB drilling, gridding, petrology and RCP drilling were conducted.

54.text: The  tenement  boundaries  and  grid  baseline  were  surveyed  by  Morris,  Hayhoe  and

55.text: Richards and plotted on AMG co-ordinates by P Kitto and Associates.

text:
Previous gold exploration work by Norgold/Geopeko on their Jackson Bore (45  Mile) 
 project included stream sediment and limited soil sampling, followed by three E-W  1 
 km  spaced  RAB  drill  hole  traverses  at  40  m  hole  intervals.  The  three  traverses  are 
 located in the northern most portion of the EL.  No  significant results >0.18  Au ppm 
 Au  were  encountered.  However,  anomalous  arsenic  values  up  to  1200  ppm  were 
 found. The exploration work failed to delineate a Bottle Creek style horizon. 
 Weak  gold  anomalies  were  found  in  stream  sediments  in  the  northern  area  of the 
 tenement.  These  are  probably  the  result  of leakage  into  the  drainage  from  the  old 
 6.  Work Completed by Townson 1991 - 1997 
 Initial  work by Townson  during  1991  included:  examination of Geopeko  data;  the 
 mapping;  coupled  with  field  inspections.  This  work  has  indicated  that  the  EL  was 
 interpretation;  1 :25000 
 Australian  Photogeological  Consultants  regional  aerial 
 prospective for a number of styles of mineralisation, including that of the Bottle Creek 
 deposits.  Followup  work  included  RAB  drilling  and  mapping.  During  1992  an 
 interpretation using stress mapping technology was completed.  From 1993-97 further 
 RAB drilling, gridding, petrology and RCP drilling were conducted. 
 The  tenement  boundaries  and  grid  baseline  were  surveyed  by  Morris,  Hayhoe  and 
 Richards and plotted on AMG co-ordinates by P Kitto and Associates.

29.text: mineralisation was  carried out in the  Datamine  graphical  user interface  (GUI)  called

35.text: Resource  modeling  has  been carried out in the  most  simplest of forms  and  is  only

36.text: presented  to  attempt  to  quantify  the  amount  of  mineralisation  identified  in  the

38.text: It is  a  constrained  model  in  the  sense  that  the  mineralisation

39.text: modelled lies within a 0.1  g/t Au envelope.  This grade is considered to represent the

40.text: 'mineralisation  indicator  grade'.  The  global  resource  identified  as  a  result  of the

43.text: 292,000 tonnes at 0. 7 glt au at a 0.25 glt Au cut-off.

44.text: Please note that this  resource  does  not  meet the  guidelines required by the AusiMM

45.text: for the reporting of "Identified Mineral Resource and Ore Resources' and as such can

46.text: not be quoted as  such for any form  of public release or publication.  It is intended to

47.text: only  provide  a  guide  for  future  exploration  and  delineate  the  potential  size  of the

49.text: Several  salient  features  have  arisen  out  of he  study  apart  from  the  figure  quoted

50.text: above, these features are as follows:-

51.text: >  A  boundary  between  the  komatite  and  porphyry  has  been  identified  and  the

52.text: contact has been modelled in three dimensions;

53.text: >  Three  main  zones  of mineralisation  has  been  identified  together  with  a  fourth

54.text: smaller zone, in order of magnitude they are as follows:

59.text: >  The drilling data is 'clean' and has been validated within the database;

60.text: >  The assay replicates have been shown to meet industry standards.

61.text: >  The assay data displays a log normal distribution and there is no .evidence of assay

62.text: 'outliers'  which  suggest poor  sampling practice  in the  field  rather than coarse or

63.text: 'nugget' gold is causing sampling problems in the lab;

text:
As an initial geological interpretation and modeling exercise, the data was exported to 
 Datamine.  The  interpretation  of  the  geological  contacts  and  the  extent  of  the 
 mineralisation was  carried out in the  Datamine  graphical  user interface  (GUI)  called 
 mineralisation  zones  have  been  presented  and  these  views  were  generated  in  the 
 the 
 Three  dimension  views  of  the  ultramafic/porphry  contact  and 
 Earthwork's programme 'Viewpoint'. 
 Resource  modeling  has  been carried out in the  most  simplest of forms  and  is  only 
 presented  to  attempt  to  quantify  the  amount  of  mineralisation  identified  in  the 
 It is  a  constrained  model  in  the  sense  that  the  mineralisation 
 modelled lies within a 0.1  g/t Au envelope.  This grade is considered to represent the 
 'mineralisation  indicator  grade'.  The  global  resource  identified  as  a  result  of the 
 modeling process is as follows:-
 292,000 tonnes at 0. 7 glt au at a 0.25 glt Au cut-off. 
 Please note that this  resource  does  not  meet the  guidelines required by the AusiMM 
 for the reporting of "Identified Mineral Resource and Ore Resources' and as such can 
 not be quoted as  such for any form  of public release or publication.  It is intended to 
 only  provide  a  guide  for  future  exploration  and  delineate  the  potential  size  of the 
 mineralisation at the 45  Mile Project. 
 Several  salient  features  have  arisen  out  of he  study  apart  from  the  figure  quoted 
 above, these features are as follows:-
 >  A  boundary  between  the  komatite  and  porphyry  has  been  identified  and  the 
 contact has been modelled in three dimensions; 
 >  Three  main  zones  of mineralisation  has  been  identified  together  with  a  fourth 
 smaller zone, in order of magnitude they are as follows: 
 •!•  Main Mineralisation Zone; 
 •!•  Footwall Mineralised Zone; 
 •!•  Hangingwall Mineralised Zone; and 
 •!•  Upper Hangingwall Mineralised Zone. 
 >  The drilling data is 'clean' and has been validated within the database; 
 >  The assay replicates have been shown to meet industry standards. 
 >  The assay data displays a log normal distribution and there is no .evidence of assay 
 'outliers'  which  suggest poor  sampling practice  in the  field  rather than coarse or 
 'nugget' gold is causing sampling problems in the lab; 
 10 
 26-09-06

50.text: proceed.  Native  Title  issues  were  not  resolved  during  2000.  In  February  2001  the

51.text: case  was  reopened  by  the  Department  of Minerals  and  Energy  under  their  new

text:
Ongoing  Native  Title  negotiations  with  the  Wutha  People  WC96/22  and  the 
 Ngurludharra/Waylan  WC95/32  were  terminated  in  late  1997,  though  agreement  in 
 principle was reached with both parties and a draft Heritage Agreement was prepared, 
 however  agreement  could  not  be  reached  with  respect  to  the  mechanism,  for 
 compensation payments.  Changes  to  the  Native  Title  Act  1993  (Wik amendments) 
 came  into  force  in October  1998.  As  a result the  Wutha have amalgamated with the 
 Sir Samuel Claim and the Ngurludharra/Waylan with the Wongatha Claim.  The case 
 was  then  put  on  hold.  Further  changes  to  administration  were  made  by  the  State 
 Liberal  Government  in  1999.  The  case  was  brought  before  the  NTT  in  2003  and 
 A review of data was  completed in  1998.  Programmes  were  planned.  Native  Title 
 developments  were  monitored  with  the  help  of the  Native  Title  Tribunal  and  Land 
 Access Unit (Department of Minerals  and  Energy).  JV  negotiations were  conducted 
 in  1999.  Native  Title  discussions  were  held.  Field  reconnaissance  was  undertaken 
 At the time of writing is  unclear how negotiations  with the new claimant groups will 
 proceed.  Native  Title  issues  were  not  resolved  during  2000.  In  February  2001  the 
 case  was  reopened  by  the  Department  of Minerals  and  Energy  under  their  new 
 negotiation  protocol  with  the  Wutha  Claimants  WC99/10,  DME  Case  No.  1303. 
 Field  inspection of the  project was  carried out.  Resource  estimation  was  reviewed. 
 26-09-06

47.text: A number of field trips were completed to the area, which included a drill programme

48.text: on Tenement M29/181.  33  RAB holes were completed to a depth of 30m each, with

49.text: sampling to be completed shortly.  A planned drill programme on tenement M291182

50.text: was put on hold whilst awaiting approval from DOIR.  This will now be completed at

51.text: a  later  date.  Several  prospecting  trips  were  carried  out  and  rock  samples  were

53.text: Results  from  prospecting  programmes  were  reasonably  promising  in

54.text: targeted area.  Next programme will focus  on several other areas. Rock samples were

55.text: collected  from  the  area  with  results  ranging  from  <0.01  to  1.25  (Au).  Field

56.text: reconnaissance was undertaken and research completed, including an aerial survey of

57.text: the region. JV discussions were conducted but no final decisions were reached.

 was  undertaken via Section  150  but this  also  failed  on  5/3/03.  The  grantee  lodged

 discussion,  various  potential  partners  were  outlined.  Initial  JV  discussion  were 
 A number of field trips were completed to the area, which included a drill programme 
 on Tenement M29/181.  33  RAB holes were completed to a depth of 30m each, with 
 sampling to be completed shortly.  A planned drill programme on tenement M291182 
 was put on hold whilst awaiting approval from DOIR.  This will now be completed at 
 a  later  date.  Several  prospecting  trips  were  carried  out  and  rock  samples  were 
 Results  from  prospecting  programmes  were  reasonably  promising  in 
 targeted area.  Next programme will focus  on several other areas. Rock samples were 
 collected  from  the  area  with  results  ranging  from  <0.01  to  1.25  (Au).  Field 
 reconnaissance was undertaken and research completed, including an aerial survey of 
 the region. JV discussions were conducted but no final decisions were reached.
